Sentence: In return for Sancho's services, Don Quixote promises to make Sancho the wealthy governor of an isle
Sancho stands by Don Quixote, often bearing the brunt of the punishments that arise from Don Quixote's behavior
Along the way, the simple Sancho plays the straight man to Don Quixote, trying his (Quixote) best to correct his (Quixote) master's outlandish fantasies
As the two embark on their journey, Sancho lies to Don Quixote, telling him (Quixote) that an evil enchanter has transformed Dulcinea into a peasant girl
Undoing this enchantment, in which even Sancho comes to believe, becomes Don Quixote's chief goal

They make a servant dress up as Merlin, for example, and tell Don Quixote that Dulcinea's enchantment--which they know to be a hoax--can be undone only if Sancho whips himself 3,300 times on his (Sancho) naked backside
Under the watch of the Duke and Duchess, Don Quixote and Sancho undertake several adventures
Cervantes becomes a party to his (Cervantes) own fiction, even allowing Sancho and Don Quixote to modify their own histories and comment negatively upon the false history published in their names
